Description: A terracotta figure of a devotee of Isis, standing, wearing a tunic and an Isis-mantle, and also a double-wreath with a fillet and with lotus buds at the top, its bindings falling on her shoulders. She has Isis-locks and bracelets, and holds a tambour against her left shoulder; her right arm is akimbo, with her hand on her hip. The back is entirely lost and fragments are missing below her left elbow and below knee level. Two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt. Traces of a white dressing with orange-pink paint in places.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: W.L. Hildburgh. Ptolemaic, second to first century BC. Comparanda: Close: Dunand 1990: no. 530, dated Roman period = Ziegler 1977: 211, pl. 18c, described as Isis; Fischer 1994: no. 886, devotee of Isis, dated first half of first century BC; Tsujimura 1998: 18, fig. 21 and back cover, from a Ptolemaic context at Akoris; Van Wijngaarden 1958: no. 69. Near: Allen 1985: no. 80, from Karanis, dated second half of third century AD; Vogt 1924: pl. xcviii:3; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 88:4; Weber 1914: no. 241, acquired in Luxor. Bibliog: Fischer 1994: 90n. 172 and 354, no. 886.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3159)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Dr W L Hildburgh
